editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: To the High, Noble and mo≈øt vertuous, CHARLES, Prince of Wales, Duke of Cornewall, Earle of Che≈øter, and Heire Apparant to the Crowne and Monarchie of Great BRITTAINE, his Gracious LORD,
All happie increa≈øe of Grace and Glorie heauenly, and earthly, from GOD the FATHER, and from our Lord IESVS CHRIST.
div.p:
MO≈øt Gracious, and mo≈øt hopefully Pui≈ø≈øant Prince, Place may yeeld much preiudice again≈øt the per≈øonall performance of any good actions, to tho≈øe mens conceits, who make cu≈øtome a vertue, with
the blinde Phari≈øes, thus taunting at NICODEMVS; John 7.52. Art thou al≈øo of Galilee? ≈øearch and looke: for out of Galiee ari≈øeth no Prophet.

But ≈øuch ≈øini≈øter thoughts God in his prouidence ≈øo graciou≈øly preuenteth, that as the Sunne ≈øhineth in euery Climate; and fruits are there found proportionable to the mea≈øure of cele≈øtiall influence ≈øhed downe by the Spheres-orbicular motions and light to the ≈øame place: ≈øo Chri≈øt is preached euery where, and pious plants are there di≈øcouered, an≈øwerable to that mea≈øure of ≈øauing Grace, which God in his mercie, by the vniformely working motions of his free Spirit, and light of his Truth, vouch≈øafeth to ≈øend them, as Peter ≈øaid in his Sermon to CORNELIVS, Act. 10.34.35 Of a truth, I perceive, that God is no respecter of per≈øons; but in euerie Nation hee that feareth GOD, and worketh righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, is accepted with him.

My hearts true comfort is then well ≈øetled by a full a≈ø≈øurance of right good acceptance, in offering to your Gracious Highne≈ø≈øe, this ≈ømall reward of a poore Prophet, ≈øince the place whence it commeth is priuiledged
from preiudice, it being your Highne≈ø≈øe owne Principalitie of Wales.

For albeit ≈øome Iohn Penrie again≈øt the vnlearned Mini≈øters in Wales to the Right Honourable Lord, Henrie, Earle of Pembroke, Lord Pre≈øident of the Marches of Wales. Schi≈ømatically-ra≈øh Cen≈øurers, in times pa≈øt, layd an heauie a≈øper≈øion of a Galilaean barrenne≈ø≈øe vpon this Countrie, for want of Prophets and Prophets Children therein: yet God bee thanked, their complaint was cau≈øele≈ø≈øe, ≈øince not to rifle vp any olde Rowles and Regi≈øters of the Ancient Brittaines, great endeuours, and good proceedings in all holy Learning, and deepe Literature, God no ≈øooner ≈øent the beames of his Go≈øpell to ≈øhine vpon this Hemi≈øphere of the Reformed Church of Great Brittaine: but pre≈øently Wales was, as well as other places of this Kingdome, comforted with the warmth of this heauenly Light, conueyed thereinto, euen through the hard ≈øtormes of tho≈øe Antichri≈øtian Per≈øecutions in former times, by the faithfull Mini≈øterie of ble≈ø≈øed Bi≈øhop Farrar, Rawlins, White, and other at Gloce≈øter, Worce≈øter, &c. burnt. Martyrs and glorious Confe≈ø≈øors, and now continued, yea, and mightily encrea≈øed by the faithfull paines of zealous Pa≈øtors, our Right Reuerend Fathers, and pious Pre≈øbyters, who
Iohn 5.35. like ≈øhining and burning Candles,
haue ≈øo cleered the≈øe Coa≈øts of the Clouds of Popi≈øh Ignorance, that Wales is like Galilee in the dayes of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, The
Mat. 4.16.17 people which ≈øate in darkne≈ø≈øe, ≈øeeing great light. A full proofe whereof your Graces Highne≈ø≈øe daily findeth by the growth of godline≈ø≈øe in Per≈øons of all ≈øorts, by the loyall obedience of all true-hearted Subiects, and by the con≈øtant ob≈øeruance of all good Orders ≈øet downe mo≈øt intirely, by tho≈øe mo≈øt Honourable, Godly, and Prudent Sages of his Maie≈øties Councell, within the≈øe Marches, of who≈øe ≈øincere Gouernment and Guidance of this your Highne≈ø≈øe Principalitie, I mu≈øt needes ≈øay as I finde, the Lord the Searcher of all hearts, knowing that I lye not, in the wordes of EVRIPIDES, Euripid. in Antiope apud Tholo≈øanum lib. „Äà‚óä„Äâ . de Rep. cap. 1
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ : By the ≈øentence of the≈øe men, the Cities are well inhabited, and ≈øo is the Hou≈øe; al≈øo they are helpfull to Warlike affaires.

For the≈øe fiue yeeres together, I being called through Gods meere Prouidence, by the ≈øole care and fauour of a mo≈øt Worthie Sir Edward Herbert, Knight of the Bath. Per≈øonage for all deepe Learning, and truely tryed valour, to his immortall
honour, into this parcell of GODS true Vineyard, can te≈øtifie with all boldne≈ø≈øe the happie ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of tho≈øe true paines, which God hath in his mercy ble≈ø≈øed to the comfort of vs his poore Seruants, that we labour not in vaine; Iohn 4.36. reaping and receiving wages, and gathering fruit vnto life eternall.

The liuely ≈øtrength of which great encouragements hath and doth animate me Gods poore Creature, to ≈øpend all ≈øpare time from the ordinarie execution of my nece≈ø≈øarie Function in preaching GODS Word vpon the Lords Day, and at other fit ≈øea≈øons, in writing out and publi≈øhing ≈øuch of my Sermons, as are iudged by my Hearers to bee mo≈øt profitable, that what was lo≈øt in hearing, may by reading be recouered, and what was well heard, might better bee holden; by the Example of the olde Vid. Danaeum cap. 20. Prolegom, in M ‚Ä¢ nor. Prophetas. Prophets and the Apo≈øtles of Chri≈øt, who preaching much, yet penned no more then what Gods Spirit thought fit and profitable for the pre≈øent, and to future Ages. And ≈øo vpon this ≈øettled re≈øolution, which I tru≈øt in God, good men will iudge truely hone≈øt, I fa≈øtened my Studies for ≈øome
time vpon this Sermon, preached long ≈øince, yet fre≈øhly de≈øired to bee publi≈øhed for their benefit, by diuers godly Learned, e≈øpecially, for that our Antichri≈øtian Aduer≈øaries ≈øeemed much di≈øcontented, that their Pope ≈øhould be arraigned and adiudged to bee that Great Antichri≈øt; and them≈øelues to be prooued ≈øo plainly Antichri≈øtian, euen open Rebels to Chri≈øt and Chri≈øtian Princes, whereas (as they thinke) in the Theorique part, Andreas Eudaemon hath an≈øwered our obiections, and for the practique, their loyaltie is approoued in the ≈øight of GOD and Man.

Indeed this Argument is the very roote of all the differences betweene them and vs, vpon which, after ≈øo many Great Learned Men, I doe not pre≈øume to deliuer more then hath beene ≈øaid, but only to refre≈øh the Memories of the Learned, with a new Method of olde matters; both replying vpon Eudaemon, where he ≈øeemeth to pre≈ø≈øe, and explayning the mi≈øerie of our en≈ølaued Countrymen vnder the Pope.

Al which I mo≈øt humbly pre≈øent to your Highne≈ø≈øe, as to whom the execution of
mo≈øt things here mentioned may chiefly belong, for the rooting out of Antichri≈øt, and vtter extirpation of the Romi≈øh Babylon; ≈øince what God hath begunne by the Gracious hand of our mo≈øt Learned, Wi≈øe, Godly, and Pui≈ø≈øant Soueraigne for the detection of that Man of Sinne, Your Graces Highne≈ø≈øe in Hereditarie imitation may fini≈øh in due time, to the Glory of God, in maintenance of Truth, and your owne eternall Honour, by ≈øettling Gods people in this happy, healthfull, and orderly peace. The God of Power and Grace ≈øo ble≈ø≈øe your Excellencies Highnes with all the rich Endowments of his holy Spirit, that with the full encrea≈øe of all true Honour, your Grace may pa≈ø≈øe many many good dayes here on Earth, in all Peace and Godline≈ø≈øe, with the ≈øealed a≈ø≈øurance of endle≈ø≈øe Happine≈ø≈øe, in the heauenly Ieru≈øalem, with the general A≈ø≈øembly and Church of the Fir≈øt-borne in Ie≈øus Chri≈øt. Amen.
